paragraph.docTitle:
Evidence of altitudinal gradient modifying genomic and chemical diversity in populations of
Lychnophora pinaster Mart.

subSection.paragraph: Genetic diversity
Essential oil
Sesquiterpene
SNP
ABSTRACT

Lychnophora pinaster Mart. (Asteraceae)
is endemic to the Brazilian Cerrado. It is distributed along the altitudinal gradient of the mountainous ranges of the state of Minas Gerais . This study aimed to evaluate the influence of altitude on the genetic diversity of
L. pinaster
populations and the effects of altitude and climatic factors on essential oil chemical composition. Essential oils from
L. pinaster
populations from the north (North 01, North 02, and
North 03, 700
–859 m) and the Metropolitan region of Belo Horizonte (MhBH 01 and MrBH 02, 1366–1498 m ) were analyzed. SNP markers from
L. pinaster
in these regions and Campos das Vertentes (CV 01, CV 02, and CV 03, 1055–1292 m ) were also analyzed. The main compounds in essential oils were 14-hydroxy-α- humulene (North 01 and North 03), cedr-8(15)-en-9-α- ol (North 02), 14-acetoxy-α- humulene (MrBH 01), and 4-oxo-15-noreudesman-11-ene (MrBH 02). Hierarchical cluster and heatmap analyses showed that the North and MrBH populations included five different groups, indicating the chemical composition of essential oils is distinct in each population. Furthermore, principal component analysis showed that higher altitudes ( 1366 m and 1498 m ) in the MrBH influence the chemical composition of essential oils, and climatic factors determine the chemical composition in North region. The genetic diversity showed that most alleles are in Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium and imply high genetic variation and genetic polymorphisms between populations. Furthermore, the results of Mantel tests (R = 0.3861517; p = 0.04709529; R = 0.9423121; p = 0.02739726) also showed that higher altitude ( > 1360 m ) shapes the genetic diversity at the MrBH. The genetic structure showed that higher altitudes ( > 1360 m ) contribute to the structure of the MrBH populations, but not to North and CV populations. Therefore, the altitudinal ranges of Minas Gerais mountainous ranges determine the higher genetic and chemical diversity of
L. pinaster
populations.

The genus
Lychnophora (Asteraceae)
includes 35 species, of which 23 are found in different phytophysiognomies in the Brazilian Cerrado. This genus demonstrates wide interspecies morphological variation, including sizes of treelet, shrub, and (rarely) subshrub and presence of slightly branched stem branches, alternate sessile leathery and sheathless leaves, terminal inflorescences, and cypselae with inconspicuous carpopodia ( Semir et al., 2011 ; de Andrade Wagner et al., 2014 ; Loeuille et al., 2015 , 2019 ).
Lychnophora
is a chemically complex genus with great structural diversity of specialized metabolites, such as sesquiterpene hydrocarbons, oxygenated sesquiterpenes, flavonoids, and sesquiterpene lactones ( Semir et al., 2011 ).

Lychnophora pinaster Mart.
, known as “arnica” and “arnica mineira,” is an endemic species at risk of extinction located in the
campo rupestre
of the Brazilian Cerrado of Minas Gerais . The aerial parts are used in traditional medicine in alcoholic preparations to treat inflammation, contusions, sprains, bruises, insect bites, and other injuries ( Rodrigues and Carvalho, 2001 ; Semir et al., 2011 ). Previous studies have demonstrated the presence of compounds in
L. pinaster
with trypanocidal (caffeic acid, isochlorogenic acid, vitexin, isovitexin), antibacterial and anti-inflammatory (α- amyrin, quercetin, lupeol, stigmasterol, sitosterol), analgesic and antipyretic (friedelin) actions, corroborating popular use ( Silveira et al., 2005 ; Abreu et al., 2011 ; Abreu et al., 2013 ).

Angelica archangelica
L. populations collected at three high altitudes in India (3500, 3200, and 2200 m ) produced limonene, γ- terpinene, terpinolene, and bornyl acetate ( Chauhan et al., 2016 ). Essential oils of H. italicum
ssp. microphyllum
populations collected in the mountain ( 600–1250 m ) and coastal ( 0–60 m ) regions of Italy contained different chemical compositions: individuals from mountainous regions had significant geraniol, α- cis/trans -bergamotene, and α- guaiene concentrations, while those from coastal regions had significant nerolidol, cis -β- guaiol and trans -caryophyllene concentrations ( Melito et al., 2016 ).

In Brazil , the Cerrado biome is marked by extreme abiotic factors ( De Almeida et al., 2016 ; Alkmim et al., 2018 ), especially in the state of Minas Gerais . The evolution of the Cerrado biome in Minas Gerais contributed to the appearance of many endemic species ( Loeuille et al., 2015 ) so that it is possible to find a large number of endemic species associated with mountainous complexes ( Semir et al., 2011 ; Alkmim et al., 2018 ).
Lychnophora pinaster
is found in the
campo rupestre
located in the mountain ranges ( Semir et al., 2011 ) with wide variation in altitude (
800–2000 m
), soil, and climate conditions. The altitudinal variation of the mountain ranges of Minas Gerais can function as a geographical barrier for
L. pinaster
populations, reflected in the diversity and genetic structure of the population and consequent intra- and interpopulation genetic divergences. In addition, the action of climatic factors caused by altitude variations can promote variations in the chemical composition of essential oils as a response mechanism to the xeromorphic and seasonal environment of the
campo rupestre
, increasing the chemical diversity of the species. However, little is known about the effects of altitudinal variations on the chemical composition of essential oils and the genetic composition of
L. pinaster
. The aim of the present study was to investigate the impact of altitude variations on the genetic

diversity of
Lychnophora pinaster
populations, as well as altitude and climatic factors on the chemical composition of the species’ essential oils.

heading.emphasis: 2.1. Yield and characterization of essential oils

subSection.paragraph:
The yield of essential oils of
five
L.
pinaster populations varied from 0.05% to 0.18% ( Table 1 ), with the highest concentrations found in the North 02 population (0.18 ± 0.11). The Kendall ranking correlation analysis showed a low correlation between yield and altitude (R =

0.026, p = 0.69); hence, the altitude did not influence the production of essential oils of
L. pinaster
. Furthermore, the yield presented inter-population variation ( Table 1 ), consistent with previous reports (
Marques et al., 2020
).

The essential oils of
five
L.
pinaster populations were characterized by a complex mixture mainly composed of monoterpenes (3.6–20.0%) and sesquiterpenes (3.1–74.7%, Table 1 ). In total, 46 compounds were identified, accounting for 60.5–91.0% of the constituents of essential oils. Based on linear retention indexes and mass spectra of unidentified compounds, it could be inferred that these compounds are sesquiterpenes. However, the low abundance of these compounds did not allow their isolation, and the 1 H and 13 C NMR auxiliary techniques were used for their identification, especially for essential oils of the MrBH02 population.

Essential oils of
L. pinaster
populations contained a high abundance of oxygenated sesquiterpenes (38.5–74.7%). The main constituents were 14-hydroxy-α- humulene (North 01 and North 03 populations), cedr-8 (15)-en-9-α- ol (North 02 population), 14-acetoxy-α- humulene (MrBH 01), and 4-oxo-15-nor-eudesman-11-ene for the MrBH 02 population ( Table 1 ).

The predominant chemical constituent of essential oils of the MrBH02 population was identified as norsesquiterpene 4-oxo-15-noreudesman-11-ene based on 1 D ( 1 H and 13 C NMR; DEPT) and 2D (HSQC and HMBC) NMR data. The correlations observed in the HMBC experiment between the hydrogens at δ 2.47 and 2.37 (H-6) with carbons at δ 214.81 (J-3), 152.91 (J-3), 44.35 (J-2), and 33.84 (J-3) are compatible with 15-nor-eudesman and also justify the carbonyl positioned in C-4. Furthermore, the 15-nor-eudesman-type sesquiterpenoids have been isolated from Asteraceae species ( Wu et al., 2006 ); they are characterized by NMR here for the first time from genus
Lychnophora .

Although the North 02 and North 03 populations were close ( 8 km apart, Table S1 , Fig. 1 ), the major constituents were divergent. The same pattern was observed for the MrBH 01 and MrBH 02 populations found 23 km apart.

The cluster analysis (HCA) showed that the North and MrBH populations of
L. pinaster
were chemically distinct, generating five groups ( Fig. 2 ). Furthermore, the heatmap ( Fig. 3 ) generated as a function of the correlation coefficients of the substances from the
L. pinaster
populations shows that each population contained a group of highly correlated compounds not found in the others. The North 01 population was strongly correlated with 13 compounds, especially α- copaen-11-ol, spathulenol, and mirtenal, and in the North 02 population, these compounds were mainly cis -caryophyllene, caryophyllene oxide, cedr-8(15)- en-9-α- ol, 14-hydroxy-( Z )-caryophyllene, and γ- curcumen-15- al. The North 03 population strongly correlated with 14 compounds; it was the only population containing epi -longipinanol, sesquiterpenes 2 and 3, and dehydroxy-( E )-linalool oxide.

The MrBH 01 population strongly correlated with 19 substances, including geranyl acetate, viridiflorol, tridecanal, and (2 E )-tridecenol acetate, detected only in this population. The MrBH 02 population contained 18 compounds, of which sabinene, o -cymene, α- thujene, terpinene, and α- terpineol were not detected in other populations.

The chemical composition of essential oils also showed interpopulation variation ( Table 1 ) previously described for
L. pinaster
(Reis et al.,

subSection.paragraph:
2010;
Marques et al., 2020
) and essential oils of
L. ericoides Mart. ( Lyra et al., 2008 )
. The chemical composition of essential oils of
L. pinaster
suggests genetic differences between populations and the influence of climatic conditions and altitude variations in the different regions where
the species occurs.
Results of PCA ( Fig. 4 and Tables S2 and S 3 ) demonstrate the

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. The Population distribution and collection sites of
Lychnophora pinaster
at Minas Gerais state, Brazil.

subSection.paragraph: The MrBH altitude varied between 1200 and 2000 m ( Alkmim et al., 2018 ; Barros and Magalh˜aes Jr., 2018). The altitudinal gradient changed the chemical composition and genetic diversity of species ( Moustafa et al., 2016 ) by the action of different environmental patterns, which lead to different genetic selection between populations of a species ( Wilson et al., 2013 ) and, therefore, local adaptation (García-Fern´andez et al., 2012).

Our results show that the different regions of
L. pinaster
occurrence and mountain ranges act as natural geographic barriers for the populations, contributing to isolation and genetic population differentiation, and these factors combined with the environment, including altitude and climate, shape the plant metabolism, resulting in the production of essential oils with different chemical compositions. influence of environmental variables ( Table S3 ) on the chemical composition of essential oils. The chemical composition of essential oils diverged between the MrBH and North populations. Altitude influenced the chemical composition of the MrBH populations ( 1366 m and 1498 m ), while climatic variables influenced the North populations ( 700 m – 860 m ). In addition to altitude, the MrBH 01 population was also influenced by daily temperature variation and the MrBH 02 population by rainfall. The MrBH 01 population differed by high relative proportions of β- elemene, cumacrene, tridecanal, viridiflorol, geranyl acetate, and 14-acetoxy-α- humulene. The MrBH 02 population had a high relative proportion of terpinolene, α- thujene, β- copaen-4α- ol, undecanal, α- terpineol, terpinene, limonene, sabinene, and o -cymene ( Table S2 ).

heading.emphasis: 2.2. Effects of altitude on the genetic variation based on SNP markers

subSection.paragraph:
High mountain range altitudes alter the genetic diversity of
L. pinaster
, showing different genetic pools for the sampled populations, implying that altitudes determine the genetic diversity of this species. GBS libraries retained a total of 1,173,904 loci during data processing (demultiplexing and quality of reads). After filtering data, a total of 29,731 loci containing high-quality SNP markers with 91.00 bp were found (S.D. ± 0.02, gstacks ), likely considered an excellent loci number to establish genetic diversity.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 2. Hierarchical cluster analysis (HCA) of leaf essential oils of
Lychnophora pinaster
populations and climatic factors located at the North region (North 01, North 02, and North 03), and Metropolitan region of Belo Horizonte (MrBH, MrBH 01 and MrBH 02).

subSection.paragraph:
Analysis of Molecular Variance (AMOVA) results showed that
L. pinaster
has inter-population genetic diversity (Table S4). The Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium (HWE) analysis performed on each allele per population indicated that most alleles are in equilibrium, confirmed by similar values between Ho and He (Table 02). Allele frequencies are expected to be in HWE, indicating that populations maintain their genetic diversity ( Meirmans, 2019 ). Therefore,
L. pinaster
populations demonstrated maintenance of their genetic diversity in this study. Furthermore, results showed that all
L. pinaster
populations have low nucleotide diversity, which implies genetic variation of genetic polymorphisms between populations. These populations undergo fragmentation processes due to the effect of geographical barriers, which has been reported previously for other species ( Ren et al., 2013 ; Tam et al., 2019 ; Xia et al., 2019 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3. Heatmap analysis of leaf essential oils of
Lychnophora pinaster
populations and climatic factors located at the North region (North 01, North 02, and North 03), and Metropolitan region of Belo Horizonte (MrBH, MrBH 01 and MrBH 02).

subSection.paragraph: The fixation index (FST) expressed by the entire set of SNPs

caption.paragraph:
Genetic diversity of
Lychnophora pinaster
populations expressed by SNP markers.

found on Campos das Vertentes region.

(0.06–0.52, Fig. 5 ) and global FST=0.3501 (Table S4) showed high genetic differentiation between regions.
Medicago citrina (Font Quer) Greuter
, endemic to the western Mediterranean, presents a strong population structure and fragmentation expressed by an overall FST value of 0.386 and high inbreeding values ( Juan et al., 2004 ). A similar pattern was found for
L. pinaster
populations. The geographical distance between populations was 8–571 km , indicating that mountainous ranges and altitudinal ranges isolate
L. pinaster
populations.

Results of the Mantel test performed between genetic matrixes (FST) and geographic distances ( Table S1 ) between populations demonstrated a high correlation value (R = 0.8036307, p = 0.0036). PCA performed with neutral and positive sets of SNPs selected by the BayeScan method ( Fig. S1 ) and by the PCAdapt method ( Fig. S2 ) also show that isolation by distance of
L. pinaster
populations contributes to the genetic diversity of the species. Admixture analyses ( Fig. 5 ) showed that regions contain distinct genetic pools, and results of the population structure also corroborate fixation index values (FST, Fig. 4 ). Mountain ranges in Minas Gerais ( Semir et al., 2011 ) contribute to the spatial segregation of
L. pinaster ,
promoting isolation by distance of the species. Isolation by distance promotes spatial allelic segregation and alters the presence of alleles among populations ( Edwards et al., 2021 ), enhancing the inter-population genetic diversity. Therefore, mountain ranges geographically isolate
L. pinaster
located in the North and MrBH regions, increasing the inter-population diversity of this species.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 5. Dendrogram and heatmap analysis for
Lychnophora pinaster
populations located at the North (North 01, North 02, and North 03), Metropolitan region of Belo Horizonte (MrBH, MrBH 01 and MrBH 02), and Campos das Vertentes (CV 01, CV 02, and CV 03) regions based on the fixation index (FST) of Wright’ s Fstatistics expressed by the full set of SNP markers.

subSection.paragraph:
Results show that the genetic diversity of
L. pinaster
populations corroborates the variation in essential oil chemical compositions. Furthermore, studies of
L. ericoides
indicate high chemical plasticity for this species regarding the location of each population and local environmental events ( Curado et al., 2006 ), showing that endemic species suffer intense selection pressures due to geography and local climate, as observed for
L. pinaster
.

The present study showed that natural
L. pinaster
populations have high chemical and genetic inter-population diversity according to the altitudinal variation ( 700 m – 1498 m ). The chemical compositions of essential oils are distinct with differential sesquiterpene production, e. g., major compounds 14-hydroxy-α- humulene (North 01 and North 03), cedr-8(15)-en-9-α- ol (North 02), 14-acetoxy-α- humulene (MrBH 01), and 4-oxo-15-nor-eudesman-11-ene (MrBH 02). Furthermore, climatic factors influence the chemical composition of
L. pinaster
populations from lower ( 700 m , 819 m , 859 m ) and higher ( 1366 m , 1498 m ) altitudes influence the chemical composition in populations located in the Metropolitan region of Belo Horizonte (MrBH 01, MrBH 02). We highlight that higher altitudes ( > 1360 m ) contribute to the population structure of the MrBH populations, but not to those of North (North 01, North 02, and North 03) or Campos das Vertentes (CV 01, CV 02, and CV 03) populations. Higher altitude also shaped the genetic diversity at MrBH by establishing a differential allele selection between populations.

The shoots of 141 individuals from eight natural
L. pinaster Mart.
populations were collected along an altitudinal gradient from
700 to 1,498 m
in the North (North 01, North 02, North 03), Metropolitan region of Belo Horizonte (MrBH 01, MrBH 02), and Campos das Strands (CV 01, CV 02, CV 03) regions of the state of Minas Gerais , Brazil . Geographic information, altitude, collection sites, and year of collections are shown in Table 3 and Fig. 1 . The distance between populations ranged from 8 to 571 km ( Table S1 ). The genetic study included all 141 individuals
.

Fig. 6. The population structure of
Lychnophora pinaster
populations. Populations structure is based on the total SNP set (A), neutral SNP set (B), and positive SNP set (C). The selection of neutral and positive SNP sets was performed by BayeScan analysis. L. pinaster

Lychnophora pinaster
populations, Minas Gerais, Brazil.

a the genetics and essential oils composition samples of North 02 and North 03 populations were collected at 2017 and 2019, respectively.

subSection.paragraph: The confirmation of taxonomic identification of the species was conducted by specialists in the genus PhD. Jo˜ao Semir from the Institute of Biology, State University of Campinas, and PhD. Marcelo Monge (Federal University of Uberlˆandia). The identifications were based on specialist knowledge, comparisons with other materials, and published literature ( Semir, 1991 ; Semir et al., 2011 ; Loeuille et al., 2019 ). Exsiccates were deposited at the UEC herbarium of the State University of Campinas (UEC 179320, 179321, 179322, 208036, 208026, 208030, 208028, and 208038). Plant material was collected by authorization of the Ministry of the Environment of Brazil (ICMBio: 22772–6; Sis- Gen/MMA: A01F803) and the Forestry Institute of the state of Minas Gerais (authorizations 005/2017 and 006/2017).

After manual separation of fresh leaves from branches, essential oils were extracted by hydrodistillation in a Clevenger apparatus for 2 h after performing pre-tests to optimize the extraction time. The yield of essential oils was calculated on a dry basis. For each sample, three portions of fresh leaves ( 1 g /portion) were taken at the time of extraction and dried in a forced-air oven at 40 ◦ C to constant weight to calculate leaf moisture. Essential oils were kept in a freezer at 20 ◦ C until further analysis.

Qualitative analysis of the chemical composition of essential oils was conducted using a QP-5000 GC-MS (Shimadzu Corporation, Kyoto , Japan ). A DB-5 capillary column ( 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) was used in GC experiments, and helium was used as carrier gas at a constant flow of 1.0 mL min 1 . The injector was kept at 220 ◦ C, injecting 1 μL of solution ( 1 mg essential oil/1 mL ethyl acetate, chromatographic grade) and a split ratio of 1:20. The GC oven temperature was programmed from 60 ◦ C to 240 ◦ C at 3 ◦ C min 1 . Electron ionization (EI) was used at 70 eV, and mass spectra were collected over the range of m/z 40–450. The transfer line was maintained at 240 ◦ C. Identification of chemical constituents was carried out by comparing mass spectra of substances with those in the database (Nist 62.lib) and linear retention indexes found in the literature ( Adams, 2017 ). Linear retention indexes were obtained from the injection of a mixture of n -alkanes (C 9 –C 24 ), using an equation described by Van den Dool and Kratz (1963) .

Quantitative analysis was performed using GC-FID (GC-2010/AOC-20i, Shimadzu Corporation, Kyoto , Japan ), and conditions were the same as for the GC-MS method. Area normalization was used to determine the percentage of essential oil components without using correction factors. The essential oils of the 82 sampled individuals were analyzed.

A sample of the essential oil of the MrBH 02 population was subjected to preparative TLC. Essential oil ( 60 mg ) was diluted with ethyl acetate (Merck, chromatographic grade), applied to a 60 F 254 silica chromatoplate (20 x 20, Merck) and eluted with a mixture of chloroform and ethyl acetate (95:5) three times. The substance was extracted from silica using methanol and dichloromethane (PA Merck). The solvent mixture was eliminated by a rotary evaporator and yielded compound 4- oxo-15-nor-eudesman-11-ene ( 25 mg ).

Nuclear magnetic resonance ( 1 H and 13 C NMR), heteronuclear single quantum correlation (HSQC), and heteronuclear multiple bond correlation (HMBC) were used to identify 4-oxo-15-nor-eudesman-11-ene. 1 D and 2 D NMR spectra were acquired on Brucker Inova 500 and Brucker Fourier 300 spectrometers, respectively, using CDCl 3 as a solvent, with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal standard.

The genetic analyses were performed on
eight
L.
pinaster populations ( Table 3 ). The CTAB method ( Doyle and Doyle, 1987 ) was applied to extract DNA from
141
L.
pinaster individuals using 10 mg of leaves per individual. DNA was quantified using agarose gel electrophoresis and

SYBERtm Safe DNA Gel Stain
(Thermo Fisher Scientific) and comparing with known lambda phage concentrations (25, 30, 50, and 100 ng /μL). DNA samples were normalized to 20 ng /μL and purified using the QIAquick PCR Purification of Qiagen ® kit. Samples were stored in a biofreezer at 80 ◦ C for further use.

heading.emphasis: 4.5.2. Preparation of genomic libraries via next-generation sequencing

subSection.paragraph:
The protocol for the construction of GBS genomic libraries was carried out according to
Poland et al. (2012)
, with modifications as described in Zucchi et al. (2019) . A total of 20 ng /μL DNA per individual was used to construct GBS libraries, which was normalized to 10 μL.

Demultiplex procedures, construction of RAD loci , discovery, and annotation of SNP markers were conducted via pipeline in STACKS v.2.45 ( Catchen et al., 2013 ; Cordeiro et al., 2019 ; Zucchi et al., 2019 ). Reads of
L. pinaster
samples were first demultiplexed using the radtags software and individualized into different files in the. fastq format based on each sample’ s barcodes (6–8bp). Several filters were applied in this first stage to select high-quality sample reads : the quality score filter (-q), the filter for eliminating readings with the non-call based function (-c), and the function that prevents the selection of barcodes with more than one mismatch (-r). After this procedure, sequences with a length of 90 bp were selected, and low quality sequences were discarded. The second genotyping stage consisted of constructing an SNP catalog using the ustacks software. In this software, the method for SNP selection was applied because the species does not have a reference genome, followed by the following parameters: maximum allowed distance between stacks (M = 2); maximum allowed distance for secondary alignments (N = 4, M +2); and minimum coverage with three sequences for each RAD locus (m =3). The third step consisted of constructing a common SNP catalog using the cstacks software. During this process, a difference greater than two (2) between the same locus was not allowed to prevent loci from overlapping. In addition, each SNP marker was required to be present in at least 60% of total samples (-r = 0.5), with a minimum frequency restricted to 5% and observed heterozygosity (Ho) limited to a maximum of 75%.

heading.emphasis: 4.5.5. Description of SNPs under positive selection

subSection.paragraph: genotypic effects of neutral loci and loci under positive selection, establishing frequency values for each marker. The second approach to detect SNP markers under positive selection was the PCAdapt method implemented by the pcadapt package using R software ( Luu et al., 2017 ). This model also uses FST values indicated by SNP markers that make up the population structure and a series of mathematical probabilities. Furthermore, the model indicates which markers are neutral and which are under positive selection ( Luu et al., 2017 ; Zucchi et al., 2019 ). The PCAdapt model expresses PCA, showing how SNP markers can promote the selection process in populations under study.

Roberto O. Portella : conceptualization, method appliance, investigation, genomic and metabolomic data analysis, data curation, writing - original draft, project management. Erick M. G. Cordeiro : bioinformatic analysis, investigation.
Ana Paula S. Marques
: method application, investigation, writing – review. Lin C. Ming : investigation, recources. Maria I. Zucchi : genomic method appliance, investigation, genomic data analysis, writing – review & editing. Maria P. Lima : investigation, recourses, metabolomic data analysis, project management. Ernane R. Martins : sample collection, recourses, investigation. Leandro W. Hantao : metabolomic method appliance, recourses, investigation, project management. Alexandra C. H. F. Sawaya : metabolomic method appliance, recourses, investigation, writing – review & editing, project management. Jo˜ao Semir : sample identification, recourses, investigation. Jos´e B. Pinheiro : genomic method appliance, investigation, resources.
Marcia O. M. Marques
: conceptualization, method appliance, investigation, recourses, genomic and metabolomic data analysis, data curation, writing - original draft, project management, funding acquisition, funding administration.
Authors declare that they do not have competing financial interests or personal relationships that influence the work reported in this paper.

The authors would like to thank Ph.D. Prof. Marcelo Monge (Federal University of Uberlandia ˆ) and Ph.D. Prof. Joao˜Semir (State University of Campinas), in Memorium , for botanical identification.
